content:
The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 is the short title for this Act. It includes improved coordination of export promotion programs. The Act includes improved coordination of export promotion programs, consolidation of duplicative activities, clarification of roles, representation of State agencies, reporting to Congress, and enhancements to Export.gov for export information. It also focuses on developing a single window for export control compliance information to facilitate export opportunities for small businesses. The Act includes definitions, promotion of exporting, small business export matchmaking pilot program, export control education, inter-agency task force on export financing, and availability of State resource guides on Export.gov. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is being amended to include identifying opportunities for office consolidation, coordinating electronic databases, and providing detailed listings of trade activities. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is being amended to include providing detailed listings of current and future Federal and State-led trade missions, trade fairs, and related activities for better service delivery to U.S. businesses. The Secretary of Commerce will make this information available on Export.gov or a successor website. SEC. 102. CLARIFICATION OF ROLES OF MEMBERS OF TRADE PROMOTION COORDINATING COMMITTEE. Section 2312(c) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify the roles of each department or agency in export promotion and financing activities. It includes identifying roles, describing goals and objectives, and measuring and reporting on those goals. Congress is also included in the reporting process. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify department roles in export promotion. This includes describing goals, measuring and reporting on them, and involving Congress in the process. Recommendations from the Comptroller General regarding coordination are also included. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify department roles in export promotion, including goals, measurement, reporting, and involving Congress. Recommendations from the Comptroller General on coordination are also included, along with changes to the United States National Tourism Organization to the United States Travel Association. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to include a representative of state agencies on the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee. Additionally, reports to Congress regarding the committee's activities are required. Section 2312(f) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to require the chairperson of the TPCC to submit an annual report to Congress detailing the strategic plan, its implementation, revisions, and the implementation of sections 303 and 304 of the FREEDOM Support Act. Additionally, the inspector general of the Department of Commerce must also submit reports to Congress. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce prepares and submits an annual report to Congress on the TPCC's performance in carrying out its duties and implementing the strategic plan. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce submits an annual report to Congress on the TPCC's performance and strategic plan implementation, consulting with other federal agencies' inspectors general. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce consults with other federal agencies' inspectors general and appropriate congressional committees regarding the TPCC. SEC. 105. REPORT ON IMPROVEMENTS TO EXPORT.GOV AS A SINGLE WINDOW FOR EXPORT INFORMATION. The Director of International Trade of the Small Business Administration will submit a report to Congress within 180 days of this Act's enactment, with recommendations for enhancing Export.gov as a comprehensive resource for exporters to submit required information to the Federal Government. The curr_chunk provides a detailed outline of the entities specified in the subsection, including small business concerns and various government agencies involved in export promotion. It emphasizes the need for a single website for exporters to submit required information to the Federal Government. The curr_chunk discusses the need for a single window for information on export control compliance. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration will submit a report on the benefits of creating a website as a comprehensive resource for export control laws and regulations. This website would also serve as a single platform for exporters to submit required information to the Federal Government. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives related to commerce, science, small business, and entrepreneurship. TITLE II--FACILITATION OF EXPORT OPPORTUNITIES FOR SMALL BUSINESSES

SEC. 201. DEFINITIONS.

    In this title, the terms "Administration" and "Administrator" refer to the Small Business Administration and its Administrator, respectively. The term "region of the Administration" is defined in section 3(u) of the Small Business Act, and "small business concern" is defined in section 3 of the Small Business Act.

SEC. 202. PROMOTION OF EXPORTING.

    Amendment to Section 22(c)(11) of the Small Business Act requires conducting at least one outreach event promoting exporting as a business development opportunity for small business concerns in each State annually. SEC. 202. PROMOTION OF EXPORTING. Amends Small Business Act to require conducting outreach events in each State promoting exporting as a business opportunity for small businesses. SEC. 203. SMALL BUSINESS EXPORT MATCHMAKING PILOT PROGRAM. SEC. 203. SMALL BUSINESS EXPORT MATCHMAKING PILOT PROGRAM. The Administrator will establish a pilot program to conduct matchmaking events in each region to connect small businesses with potential foreign buyers. At least 1 event per region per year will be held, and events may be coordinated with outreach events. The program authority will end on September 30, 2015. SEC. 204 amends the Small Business Act to prioritize educating small businesses on Federal export control regulations. SEC. 205 establishes a Small Business Inter-Agency Task Force on Export Financing. SEC. 205 establishes a Small Business Inter-Agency Task Force on Export Financing to review and improve Federal export finance programs for small businesses and coordinate government activities to assist small businesses in exporting. The Secretary of Commerce will provide State resource guides on Export.gov, detailing export promotion and financing resources in each State, including State agencies, district export councils, and trade associations.
